Toolbar overview linkcodeopen\_in\_new menuMy Appfavoriteshare ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/toolbar/overview\#single-row) Single row In the simplest case, a toolbar may be placed at the top of your application and have a single row that includes the title of your application. Toolbar with just text linkcodeopen\_in\_new My Application ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/toolbar/overview\#multiple-rows) Multiple rows The Material Design spec used to describe toolbars with multiple rows. This can be done by placing `` elements inside a ``. content\_copy ``` Custom Toolbar ``` **Note**: Placing content outside a `` when multiple rows are specified is not supported. ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/toolbar/overview\#positioning-toolbar-content) Positioning toolbar content The toolbar does not perform any positioning of its content. This gives the user full power to position the content as it suits their application. A common pattern is to position a title on the left with some actions on the right. This can be easily accomplished with `display: flex`: content\_copy ``` Second Line verified_user ``` content\_copy ``` .example-spacer { flex: 1 1 auto; } ``` ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/toolbar/overview\#accessibility) Accessibility By default, the toolbar assumes that it will be used in a purely decorative fashion and thus sets no roles, ARIA attributes, or keyboard shortcuts. This is equivalent to having a sequence of `
` elements on the page. Generally, the toolbar is used as a header where `role="heading"` would be appropriate. Only if the use-case of the toolbar match that of role="toolbar", the user should add the role and an appropriate label via `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby`.
